user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Timer_NoArgCallback:
```c
static void OS_Timer_NoArgCallback(osal_id_t objid, void *arg)
{
    OS_Timer_ArgWrapper_t Conv;

    /*
     * Note - did not write this as simply *((OS_SimpleCallback_t)arg) because
     * technically you cannot cast a void * to a function pointer.
     */
    Conv.opaque_arg = arg;
    (*Conv.timer_callback_func)(objid);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_Timer_NoArgCallback:
typedef union
{
    OS_TimerCallback_t timer_callback_func;
    void *             opaque_arg;
} OS_Timer_ArgWrapper_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The target function OS_Timer_NoArgCallback and the related definitions contain no use of the C standard library function memcmp, nor any other string-comparison functions (strcmp, strncmp, etc.). The code only manipulates a union containing a function pointer and a void* and invokes that function pointer; there are no char* or null-terminated string operations present. Therefore there are no code fragments in the provided snippet that could violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14. If memcmp-based string comparisons exist, they would be located outside the supplied code and would need to be identified in those other files for review.
